Explanations about Options.-perm:
Any of the permission bits mode are set for the file. Symbolic modes are accepted
 in this form. You must specify `u', `g' or `o' if you use a symbolic mode. See
 the EXAMPLES section for some illustrative examples. If no permission bits in mode
 are set, this test matches any file (the idea here is to be consistent with the
 behaviour of -perm -000).
Explanations about Options.-print0:
Always print the exact filename, unchanged, even if the output is going to a
 terminal.
Explanations about Options.-name:
This option is supported, but POSIX conformance depends on the POSIX conformance of
 the system's fnmatch(3) library function. As of findutils-4.2.2, shell
 metacharacters (`*', `?' or `[]' for example) will match a leading `.', because
 IEEE PASC interpretation 126 requires this. This is a change from previous
 versions of findutils.

Explanations about Options.-0:
Input items are terminated by a null character instead of by whitespace, and the
 quotes and backslash are not special (every character is taken literally).
 Disables the end of file string, which is treated like any other argument. Useful
 when input items might contain white space, quote marks, or backslashes. The GNU
 find -print0 option produces input suitable for this mode.
Explanations about Options.-I:
Replace occurrences of replace-str in the initial-arguments with names read from
 standard input. Also, unquoted blanks do not terminate input items; instead the
 separator is the newline character. Implies -x and -L 1.

find.mpsum: search for files in a directory hierarchy
find.-name:
This option is supported, but POSIX conformance depends on the POSIX conformance of
 the system's fnmatch(3) library function. As of findutils-4.2.2, shell
 metacharacters (`*', `?' or `[]' for example) will match a leading `.', because
 IEEE PASC interpretation 126 requires this. This is a change from previous
 versions of findutils.

xargs.mpsum: build and execute command lines from standard input

grep.-l:
Suppress normal output; instead print the name of each input file from which output
 would normally have been printed. The scanning will stop on the first match.

Explanations about Options.-n: like -l, but list numeric user and group IDs
Explanations about Options.-a: do not ignore entries starting with .
Explanations about Options.-c:
with -lt: sort by , and show , ctime (time of last modification of file status
 information); with -l: show ctime and sort by name; otherwise: sort by ctime,
 newest first
Explanations about Options.-x: list entries by lines instead of by columns
Explanations about Options.-m: fill width with a comma separated list of entries

Answers.MP Summary: presumably creating or updating package.json and running any other initialization-related operations. The init command is transformed to a corresponding npx operation as follows: · npm init foo -> npx create-foo · npm init @usr/foo -> npx @usr/create-foo · npm init @usr -> npx @usr/create Any  additional  options  will  be passed directly to the command, so npm init foo --hello will map to npx create-foo --hello. If the initializer is omitted (by just calling npm init), init will fall  back  to  legacy init  behavior.  It  will  ask you a bunch of questions, and then write a package.json for you. It will attempt to make reasonable guesses based on  existing  fields,  dependencies, and  options selected. It is strictly additive, so it will keep any fields and values that were already set. You can also use -y/--yes to skip the questionnaire altogether.  If  you pass --scope, it will create a scoped package. See Also · https://github.com/isaacs/init-package-json · npm help package.json · npm help version · npm help scope April 2020                                NPM-INIT(1)
